explanation:
- languages: The outer for-loop second clause reads languages[language_idx].dirname. You must know the declaration/definition of the languages array to determine if evaluating that expression has side effects or if any called function in the loop body can modify languages (or its elements), which would violate the MISRA constraint that the second clause must not use objects modified in the loop body.
- categories: The inner for-loop second clause reads categories[category_idx]. You must know the declaration/definition of the categories array to determine whether it can be modified by functions called in the loop body (or whether evaluating it has side effects), which would affect clause (2).
- struct Language: The loop tests languages[language_idx].dirname and uses language->longname. You need the struct Language definition to know the types of dirname/longname (e.g. whether they are simple pointers vs. accessors/macros or volatile) and whether reading them can have side effects or alias other modifiable objects.
- list_directory: This function is called inside the inner loop body. The MISRA rule requires that the behaviour of the loop body (including called functions) not modify objects used in the loop clauses (languages, categories) nor the loop counters. You must inspect list_directory to ensure it does not modify languages, categories, or the loop counters (directly or via globals/aliases), nor cause side effects that invalidate the loop tests.
- update_cached_response: Called from the loop body on error paths. You must inspect it to ensure it does not modify languages, categories, or the loop counters (or other objects used in the loop clauses) as part of its behaviour.

(Other standard library functions used in the body—stat, snprintf, memcpy, malloc, free—normally have no effect on these loop-control objects; the symbols above are the relevant additional items to inspect to determine compliance with the MISRA for-loop rule.)
